title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement b-cubedsupport@meisebotanicgarden.. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to b3gbi
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to b3gbi
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to b3gbi
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("b-cubed-eu/b3gbi", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to b3gbi
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to b3gbi
text: Please note b3gbi project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Tutorial
text: goal tutorial get familiar use b3gbi package, contains number functions calculating plotting biodiversity indicators GBIF occurrence cubes. package ready official release yet, publicly available https://www.github.com/b-cubed-eu/b3gbi. explain install package computer, give quick tutorial core functions, examples. Given package unfinished undergone limited testing, possible encounter errors.

title: Tutorial
code: install.packages("b3gbi", repos = "https://b-cubed-eu.r-universe.dev")

title: Tutorial
text: Let’s look core functions b3gbi package. first one called process_cube() used import GBIF occurrence cubes .csv files R objects. simple use. need provide name location cube .csv format. Note different versions GBIF cubes floating around, format changed. Since code package created present generation came available, compatible old new cubes. old ones come additional .csv file containing taxonomic information cube. type name cube object, contents displayed custom print function within package. can see object structure using str(). cube contained tibble (tidyverse version data frame) called data, variables contain metadata. Now let’s look indicators available calculate plot. indicators registered ones actually working package. others, fully functional moment registered. available indicator listed along class, functions used calculate map /time series. next function need understand called compute_indicator_workflow(). core package, work calculating indicator done. indicator comes wrapper functions, used rather directly calling compute_indicator_workflow(). wrapper functions listed . type name indicator object, see plotted internal function package. cube objects, indicator objects contain tibble called data. case mapped indicator, tibble also sf object containing geometry information cell. indicator object belongs two specialized object classes determine handled use plot() command. First, either class ‘indicator_ts’ ‘indicator_map’. Second, class specific indicator type. can see using class() command. S3 classes (S3 one several objected oriented programming systems contained within R). final functions need interface plot functions. plot_ts() plot_map(), fact called using plot(). plot functions offer quite arguments customize output, plotting done using ggplot package, customization quite easy.   additional functions package can make use , list_species(), lists species contained cube indicator object, mostly quite simple. continued…
code: # Function 1: process_cube() # Description: Imports a data cube from a .csv file and prepares it as a processed_cube object for indicator calculations and plotting. # Inputs:  #   * Argument 1: data, cube in .csv format  #   * Argument 2: grid_type (optional). By default the function will attempt to determine this automatically. However, you have the option to manually specify 'eea', 'mgrs', or 'eqdgc'. If you are using a simulated cube. e.g. output by the gcube package, choose 'custom'. #   * Argument 3: first_year (optional), you can filter your cube to include only data in a certain time period, by default this will be the first year of data in your cube #   * Argument 4: last_year (optional), by default this will be the last year of data in your cube #   * Argument 5: force_gridcode (optional), this will force the function to assume a specific grid reference code, not recommended and could lead to problems downstream. # The remaining arguments are all column names. Some columns are required, some are not, but it is only necessary to provide the names if they cannot be autodetected by the function. #   * Argument 6: cols_year (optional), the name of the column containing the year of occurrence. You must have either a year or yearMonth column in your cube. #   * Argument 7: cols_yearMonth (optional), the name of the column containing the year and month of occurrence #   * Argument 8: cols_cellCode (optional), the name of the column containing the cell codes. This column is required #   * Argument 9: cols_occurrences (optional), the name of the column containing species occurrences. This column is required #   * Argument 10: cols_scientificName (optional), the name of the column containing species names. This column is required #   * Argument 11: cols_minCoordinateUncertaintyInMeters (optional), the name of the column containing the minimum coordinate uncertainty. This column is not required #   * Argument 12: cols_minTemporalUncertainty (optional), the name of the column containing the minimum temporal uncertainty. This column is not required #   * Argument 13: cols_kingdom (optional) #   * Argument 14: cols_family (optional) #   * Argument 15: cols_species (optional), you must have either a scientificName or a species column, but you do not need both #   * Argument 16: cols_kingdomKey (optional) #   * Argument 17: cols_familyKey (optional) #   * Argument 18: cols_speciesKey (required), this can be either a taxonKey or speciesKey #   * Argument 19: cols_familyCount (optional) #   * Argument 20: cols_sex (optional) #   * Argument 20: cols_lifeStage (optional) # # Outputs: #   * processed_cube object containing the data cube as output_object$data along with various metadata. #     metadata include: range of years (as first_year and last_year),  #                                               coordinate range (as xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax),  #                                               number of grid cells (num_cells),  #                                               number of species Species Occurrences #>      Class: spec_occ #>      Calculate map: yes, e.g. spec_occ_map(my_data_cube) #>      Calculate time series: yes, e.g. spec_occ_ts(my_data_cube) #>      Additional map function arguments: none #>      Additional time series function arguments: none #>  #> 15. Species Range #>      Class: spec_range #>      Calculate map: yes, e.g. spec_range_map(my_data_cube) #>      Calculate time series: yes, e.g. spec_range_ts(my_data_cube) #>      Additional map function arguments: none #>      Additional time series function arguments: none #>  #> 16. Occupancy Turnover #>      Class: occ_turnover #>      Calculate map: no #>      Calculate time series: yes, e.g. occ_turnover_ts(my_data_cube) #>      Additional map function arguments: none #>      Additional time series function arguments: none # Function 2: compute_indicator_workflow() # Description: Calculates a biodiversity indicator over time or space from a processed_cube object. Should be called by one of the wrapper functions listed below.  # Inputs:  #   * Argument 1: data, a processed_cube object #   * Argument 2: type, the type of indicator to calculate #   * Argument 3: dim_type, dimension to calculate the indicator across (time, 'ts', or space, 'map'). #   * Argument 4: ci_type (optional), type of bootstrap confidence intervals to calculate (norm, basic, perc, bca, none). Uses 'norm' by default. #   * Argument 5: cell_size (optional), the length (in km) of grid cells to use #   * Argument 6: level (optional), the scale of region to calculate over (country, continent, world). Uses the whole cube by default. #   * Argument 7: region (optional), the name of the region to calculate over (e.g. Germany, Europe). Uses the whole cube by default. #   * Argument 8: ne_type (optional), the type of natural earth data to download (countries, map units, sovereignty, geounit). Uses 'countries' by default. #   * Argument 9: ne_scale (optional), the scale of natural earth data to download (small - 110m, medium - 50m, large - 10m). Uses 'medium' by default. #   * Argument 10: output_crs (optional), the projection to use for your calculated indicator if you don't want the default. #   * Argument 11: first_year (optional), use to limit the data used to calculate the indicator to a narrower range than the cube. #   * Argument 12: last_year (optional), see first_year. #   * Argument 13: spherical_geometry (optional), if FALSE, temporarily turn off spherical geometry when calculating indicator. #   * Argument 14: make_valid (optional), call st_make_valid from the sf package to fix geometry issues if you are getting errors. #   * Argument 15: num_bootstraps (optional), set the number of bootstraps to calculate for generating confidence intervals. Uses 1000 by default. # Outputs: #   * indicator_ts or indicator_map object containing a data frame of indicator values mapped to years or grid cells, along with various metadata. #     metadata include: range of years (as first_year and last_year),  #                                               coordinate range (as xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax),  #                                               number of grid cells (num_cells),  #                                               number of species (num_species),  #                                               total number of observations (num_obs),  #                                               vector of kingdoms (kingdoms),  #                                               number of families (num_families), #                                               resolutions (resolution) # # Wrapper functions: #   * obs_richness_map(): Calculate a gridded map of observed richness #   * obs_richness_ts(): Calculate a time series (trend) of observed richness #   * cum_richness_ts(): Calculate cumulative richness over time #   * total_occ_map(): Calculate the total number of records over a gridded map #   * total_occ_ts(): Calculate the total number of records over time #   * occ_density_map(): Calculate the density of records over a gridded map #   * occ_density_ts(): Calculate the density of records over time #   * williams_eveness_map(): Calculate Williams' evenness over a gridded map #   * williams_evenness_ts(): Calculate Williams' evenness over time #   * pielou_evenness_map(): Calculate Pielou's evenness over a gridded map #   * pielou_evenness_ts(): Calculate Pielou's evenness over time #   * ab_rarity_map(): Calculate abundance-based rarity over a gridded map #   * ab_rarity_ts(): Calculate abundance-based rarity over time #   * area_rarity_map(): Calculate area-based rarity over a gridded map #   * area_rarity_ts(): Calculate area-based rarity over time #   * newness_map(): Calculate the mean year of occurrence over a gridded map #   * newness_ts(): Calculate the mean year of occurrence over time #   * tax_distinct_map(): Calculate taxonomic distinctness over a gridded map #   * tax_distinct_ts(): Calculate  taxonomic distinctness over time #   * occ_turnover_ts(): Calculate occupancy turnover over time #                        # Example: library(b3gbi) Denmark_observed_richness_map <- obs_richness_map(example_cube_1, first_year = 1980, level = "country", region = "Denmark")  #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off #> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they #> are planar #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched on Denmark_observed_richness_map #> Gridded biodiversity indicator map #>  #> Name of Indicator: Observed Species Richness  #>  #> Map of Denmark  #>  #> Projected CRS: EPSG:4326  #>  #> Coordinate range: #>      xmin      ymin      xmax      ymax  #>  8.121484 54.628857 15.137109 57.736914  #>  #> Grid cell size: 0.25 degrees  #> Number of cells: 168  #>  #> Observation years: 1980 - 2023  #> Total years with observations: 44  #>  #> Number of species represented: 106  #> Number of families represented: 31  #>  #> Kingdoms represented: Animalia  #>  #> First 10 rows of data (use n = to show more): #>  #> # A tibble: 168 × 2 #>    cellid diversity_val #>     <int>         <int> #>  1     80            21 #>  2     82             7 #>  3     83            30 #>  4     84            40 #>  5     85            43 #>  6    122            20 #>  7    123            29 #>  8    124            17 #>  9    125            32 #> 10    126            40 #> # Called by plot(). # Inputs:  #   * Argument 1: x, an indicator_ts object  #   * Argument 2: min_year (optional), earliest year to include in plot #   * Argument 3: max_year (optional), latest year to include in plot #   * Argument 4: title (optional), specify a title for the plot #   * Argument 5: auto_title (optional), specified by the calling function if title is set to "auto" #   * Argument 6: y_label_default (optional), specified by the calling function if no y_label is provided #   * Argument 7: suppress_y (optional), default is "FALSE". Set to "TRUE" to turn off y axis text #   * Argument 8: smoothed_trend (optional), default is "TRUE". Set to "FALSE" to avoid displaying only the time series, without a smoothed trend  #   * Argument 9: linecolour (optional), sets the colour of the indicator line or points. Default is darkorange.  #   * Argument 10: linealpha (optional), sets the transparency of the indicator line or points. Default is 0.8. #   * Argument 11: ribboncolour (optional), colour for bootstrapped confidence intervals. Default is goldenrod1. Set to NA if you don't want to plot the CIs. #   * Argument 12: ribbonalpha (optional), transparency for confidence interval ribbon (if CI type set to 'ribbon'. Default is 0.2. #   * Argument 13: error_alpha (optional), transparency for error bars (if CI type set to 'error_bar). Default is 1. #   * Argument 14: trendlinecolour (optional), sets the colour of the smoothed trend line. Default is blue. #   * Argument 15: trendlinealpha (optional), sets the transparency of the smoothed trend line. Default is 0.5. #   * Argument 16: envelopecolour (optional), sets the colour of the smoothed trend envelope. Default is lightsteelblue. #   * Argument 17: envelopealpha (optional), sets the transparency of the smoothed trend envelope. Default is 0.2. #   * Argument 18: smooth_cialpha (optional), sets the transparency for the smoothed lines forming the edges of the smoothed trend envelope. Default is 1. #   * Argument 19: point_line (optional) #   * Argument 20: pointsize (optional) #   * Argument 21: linewidth (optional) #   * Argument 22: ci_type (optional) #   * Argument 23: error_width (optional) #   * Argument 24: error_thickness (optional) #   * Argument 25: smooth_linetype (optional) #   * Argument 26: smooth_linewidth (optional) #   * Argument 27: smooth_cilinewidth (optional) #   * Argument 28: gridoff (optional), default is "FALSE". Set to "TRUE" to turn off grid lines on the plot   #   * Argument 29: x_label (optional), use to set a custom label for the x-axis #   * Argument 30: y_label (optional), use to set a custom label for the y-axis #   * Argument 31: x_expand (optional) #   * Argument 32: y_expand (optional) #   * Argument 33: x_breaks (optional), set the number of breaks along the x-axis #   * Argument 34: y_breaks (optional), set the number of breaks along the y-axis #   * Argument 35: wrap_length (optional), set maximum length of text allowed on a single line for the plot title # Outputs: #   * Time series plot with optional smoothed trend overlay. The plot can be further customized (beyond the provided arguments) using ggplot functions. #   * Plots can be saved using ggsave.  # Example: library(b3gbi) Denmark_observed_richness_ts <- obs_richness_ts(example_cube_1, first_year = 1980, level = "country", region = "Denmark", ci_type = "none")  #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off #> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they #> are planar #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched on #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries plot(Denmark_observed_richness_ts) # Function 4: plot_map() # Description: Plots an indicator_map object as a gridded map using ggplot. Called by plot(). # Inputs:  #   * Argument 1: x, an indicator_map object  #   * Argument 2: title (optional), specify a title for the plot #   * Argument 3: auto_title (optional), specified by the calling function if title is set to "auto" #   * Argument 4: leg_label_default (optional), legend title specified by the calling function if no leg_label is provided #   * Argument 5: xlims (optional), use to set custom map limits #   * Argument 6: ylims (optional), use to set custom map limits  #   * Argument 7: trans (optional), set transformation to apply to the legend, e.g. "log10" #   * Argument 8: breaks (optional), set custom breaks for the legend #   * Argument 9: labels (optional), set custom labels for the legend #   * Argument 10: Europe_crop_EEA (optional), default is "TRUE". Crops outlying islands when plotting a continental map of Europe using the EEA grid. You can set this to "FALSE" to show the islands, but the output will be less pretty. Will be overridden if crop_to_grid set to "TRUE". #   * Argument 11: crop_to_grid (optional), If set to "TRUE" the grid will determine the edges of the map. This argument overrides Europe_crop_EEA. Default is "FALSE". #   * Argument 12: surround (optional), default is "TRUE". Shows surrounding countries when plotting a single country. Set to "FALSE" to show only the country of interest, but output will be less pretty. #   * Argument 13: panel_bg (optional), set panel background colour. Default is "white". #   * Argument 14: land_fill_colour (optional), set colour for the land area outside of the grid. Default is "grey85". #   * Argument 15: legend_title (optional), set a custom legend title #   * Argument 16: legend_limits (optional), set custom limits for the legend #   * Argument 17: legend_title_wrap_length (optional), set maximum length of text allowed on a single line for the legend title #   * Argument 18: title_wrap_length (optional), set maximum length of text allowed on a single line for the plot title # Outputs: #   * Time series plot with optional smoothed trend overlay. The plot can be further customized (beyond the provided arguments) using ggplot functions. #   * Plots can be saved using ggsave.  # Example: library(b3gbi) Denmark_observed_richness_map <- obs_richness_map(example_cube_1, level = "country", region = "Denmark")  #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off #> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they #> are planar #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched on plot(Denmark_observed_richness_map) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries

what: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes
title: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes
text: Analyze biodiversity trends spatial patterns GBIF data cubes, using flexible indicators like richness, evenness, .

title: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes
text: Biodiversity researchers need robust standardized tools analyze vast amounts data available platforms like GBIF. b3gbi package leverages power data cubes streamline biodiversity assessments. helps researchers gain insights : Changes Time: biodiversity metrics shift throughout years. Spatial Variations: Differences biodiversity across regions, identifying hotspots areas concern. Impact Factors: different environmental variables human activities might affect biodiversity patterns.

title: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes
text: b3gbi empowers biodiversity analysis : Standardized Workflows: Simplify process calculating common biodiversity indicators GBIF data cubes. Flexibility: Calculate richness, evenness, rarity, taxonomic distinctness, Shannon-Hill diversity, Simpson-Hill diversity, . Analysis Options: Explore temporal trends create spatial maps. Visualization Tools: Generate publication-ready plots biodiversity metrics.

title: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes

code: install.packages("b3gbi", repos = "https://b-cubed-eu.r-universe.dev") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("b-cubed-eu/b3gbi")

title: General Biodiversity Indicators for Biodiversity Data Cubes
text: basic example shows calculate plot map species richness data cube containing GBIF occurrence data amphibians Europe:  -depth introduction, see tutorial: https://b-cubed-eu.github.io/b3gbi/articles/b3gbi.html.
code: # Load package library(b3gbi)  # Load GBIF data cube cube_name <- system.file("extdata", "denmark_mammals_cube_eqdgc.csv", package = "b3gbi")  # Prepare cube mammal_data <- process_cube(cube_name)  # Calculate diversity metric map_obs_rich_mammals <- obs_richness_map(mammal_data, level = "country", region = "Denmark", ne_scale = "medium")  # Plot diversity metric plot(map_obs_rich_mammals, title = "Observed Species Richness: Mammals in Denmark")

title: Calculate Rarity Over Time or Space — area_rarity_map
text: data data cube object (class 'processed_cube'). ... Arguments passed compute_indicator_workflow ci_type Type bootstrap confidence intervals calculate. (Default: "norm". Select "none" avoid calculating bootstrap CIs.) cell_size Length grid cell sides, km. (Default: 10 country, 100 continent world) level Spatial level: 'cube', 'continent', 'country', 'world', 'sovereignty', 'geounit'. (Default: 'cube') region region interest (e.g., "Europe"). (Default: "Europe") ne_type type Natural Earth data download: 'countries', 'map_units', 'sovereignty', 'tiny_countries'. (Default: "countries") ne_scale scale Natural Earth data download: 'small' - 110m, 'medium' - 50m, 'large' - 10m. (Default: "medium") output_crs CRS want calculated indicator. (Leave blank let function choose default based grid reference system) first_year Exclude data year. (Uses data cube default.) last_year Exclude data year. (Uses data cube default.) spherical_geometry set FALSE, temporarily disable spherical geometry function runs. used solve specific issues. (Default TRUE) make_valid Calls st_make_valid() sf package. Increases processing time may help getting polygon errors. (Default FALSE). num_bootstrap Set number bootstraps calculate generating confidence intervals. (Default: 1000) crs_unit_convert Force particular output CRS even different units input CRS. (Default: FALSE) shapefile_path Path external shapefile merge workflow. example, want calculate indicator particular features protected areas wetlands. invert Calculate indicator inverse shapefile (e.g. protected areas shapefile calculate indicator non protected areas)

title: Calculate Rarity Over Time or Space — area_rarity_map
text: Rarity scarcity infrequency particular species area. rare species might small population size, limited distribution, unique ecological niche (Maciel, 2021; Rabinowitz, 1981). Rarity can also biodiversity indicator summed multiple species area, may provide important insight determining conservation priorities. measured time, rarity may indicate potential threats changes environment.

title: Calculate Rarity Over Time or Space — area_rarity_map
text: Abundance-based rarity inverse proportion total occurrences represented particular species. total summed rarity grid cell year calculated (sum rarity values species present ). calculated : $$   \sum_{=1}^{S} \frac{1}{p_i} $$ S number species pi proportion occurrences represented species .

title: Calculate Rarity Over Time or Space — area_rarity_map
text: Area-based rarity inverse occupancy frequency (proportion grid cells occupied) particular species. total summed rarity grid cell year calculated (sum rarity values species present ). calculated : $$   \sum_{=1}^{S} \frac{N}{n_i} $$ S number species, N total number occupied grid cells, ni number grid cells occupied species .

title: Calculate Confidence Intervals for a Biodiversity Indicator — calc_ci
text: x data cube object indicator indicator calculated time, form data frame. *Note: 'indicator_ts' object meant called 'compute_indicator_workflow' function. ... Additional arguments passed specific indicator calculation functions. num_bootstrap Set number bootstraps calculate generating confidence intervals. (Default: 1000) ci_type Type bootstrap confidence intervals calculate. (Default: "norm". Select "none" avoid calculating bootstrap CIs.) set_rows Automatically select taxonomic information keep multiple options. Default value 1 keeps first option, usually best.

title: Check if a given CRS is in meters or degrees. — check_crs_units

title: Check if a given CRS is in meters or degrees. — check_crs_units
code: check_crs_units(crs_input)

title: Check if a given CRS is in meters or degrees. — check_crs_units
text: crs_input CRS, can EPSG code, WKT string, PROJ.4 string.

title: Check if a given CRS is in meters or degrees. — check_crs_units
text: "km" meters, "degrees" degrees. Otherwise, throws informative error.

title: Check if a given CRS is in meters or degrees. — check_crs_units
code: tryCatch({   print(check_crs_units(4326)) # EPSG:4326 (degrees)   print(check_crs_units(25832)) # EPSG:25832 (meters)   print(check_crs_units("+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs")) # PROJ.4 (degrees)   print(check_crs_units("+proj=utm +zone=32 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs")) # PROJ.4 (meters)   print(check_crs_units("+proj=somerc +lat_0=0 +lon_0=0 +k=1 +x_0=0 +y_0=0         +ellps=WGS84 +units=km +no_defs")) # Invalid CRS   print(check_crs_units("not a crs")) # Invalid CRS   print(check_crs_units("+proj=lcc +lat_1=33 +lat_2=45 +lat_0=39 +lon_0=-96         +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +datum=NAD83 +units=us-ft +no_defs")) # Invalid units }, error = function(e) {   print(e$message) }) #> [1] "could not find function \"check_crs_units\""

what: Calculate Biodiversity Indicators Over Space or Time — compute_indicator_workflow
title: Calculate Biodiversity Indicators Over Space or Time — compute_indicator_workflow
text: function provides flexible framework calculating various biodiversity indicators spatial grid time series. prepares data, creates grid, calculates indicators, formats output appropriate S3 object ('indicator_map' 'indicator_ts').

title: Calculate Biodiversity Indicators Over Space or Time — compute_indicator_workflow
code: compute_indicator_workflow(   data,   type,   dim_type = c("map", "ts"),   ci_type = c("norm", "basic", "perc", "bca", "none"),   cell_size = NULL,   level = c("cube", "continent", "country", "world", "sovereignty", "geounit"),   region = "Europe",   ne_type = c("countries", "map_units", "sovereignty", "tiny_countries"),   ne_scale = c("medium", "small", "large"),   output_crs = NULL,   first_year = NULL,   last_year = NULL,   spherical_geometry = TRUE,   make_valid = FALSE,   num_bootstrap = 1000,   crs_unit_convert = FALSE,   shapefile_path = NULL,   invert = FALSE,   ... )

title: Calculate Biodiversity Indicators Over Space or Time — compute_indicator_workflow
text: data data cube object (class 'processed_cube'). type indicator calculate. Supported options include: 'obs_richness': Observed species richness. 'total_occ': Total number occurrences. 'newness': Mean year occurrence. 'occ_density': Density occurrences. 'williams_evenness', 'pielou_evenness': Evenness measures. 'ab_rarity', 'area_rarity':  Abundance-based area-based rarity scores. 'cum_richness': Cumulative species richness. 'occ_turnover': Occupancy turnover. 'spec_range': Species range size. 'spec_occ': Species occurrences. 'tax_distinct': Taxonomic distinctness. 'hill0': Species richness (estimated coverage-based rarefaction). 'hill1': Hill-Shannon diversity (estimated coverage-based rarefaction). 'hill2': Hill-Simpson diversity (estimated coverage-based rarefaction). dim_type Dimension calculate indicator (time: 'ts', space: 'map') ci_type Type bootstrap confidence intervals calculate. (Default: "norm". Select "none" avoid calculating bootstrap CIs.) cell_size Length grid cell sides, km. (Default: 10 country, 100 continent world) level Spatial level: 'cube', 'continent', 'country', 'world', 'sovereignty', 'geounit'. (Default: 'cube') region region interest (e.g., "Europe"). (Default: "Europe") ne_type type Natural Earth data download: 'countries', 'map_units', 'sovereignty', 'tiny_countries'. (Default: "countries") ne_scale scale Natural Earth data download: 'small' - 110m, 'medium' - 50m, 'large' - 10m. (Default: "medium") output_crs CRS want calculated indicator. (Leave blank let function choose default based grid reference system) first_year Exclude data year. (Uses data cube default.) last_year Exclude data year. (Uses data cube default.) spherical_geometry set FALSE, temporarily disable spherical geometry function runs. used solve specific issues. (Default TRUE) make_valid Calls st_make_valid() sf package. Increases processing time may help getting polygon errors. (Default FALSE). num_bootstrap Set number bootstraps calculate generating confidence intervals. (Default: 1000) crs_unit_convert Force particular output CRS even different units input CRS. (Default: FALSE) shapefile_path Path external shapefile merge workflow. example, want calculate indicator particular features protected areas wetlands. invert Calculate indicator inverse shapefile (e.g. protected areas shapefile calculate indicator non protected areas) ... Additional arguments passed specific indicator calculation functions.

title: Calculate Biodiversity Indicators Over Space or Time — compute_indicator_workflow
text: S3 object containing calculated indicator values metadata.

text: S3 object classes 'indicator_map' 'indicator_ts' 'hill0' 'hill1' 'hill2' containing calculated indicator values metadata.

title: Calculate Estimated Hill Diversity Over Space or Time — hill0_map
text: Hill (1973) introduced concept Hill diversity, assumes number relative abundance species inseparable components diversity. Hill diversity uses single equation calculate multiple measures diversity varying single parameter ℓ, changes emphasis rare vs common species (Roswell et al., 2019). represents mean rarity sampled species, calculated : $$  D = \left( \sum_{=1}^{S} p_i^\ell \right)^{1/(1-\ell)}  $$D diversity, S number species, pi proportion individuals belonging species , ri rarity species , ℓ determines rarity scale mean. ℓ can theoretically take almost value, three common measures diversity special cases: species richness, modified versions Shannon Simpson diversity indices (Roswell et al., 2019). three measures occur ℓ takes value 1, 0 (near-zero, ℓ actually take value 0), -1, respectively. Species Richness (ℓ = 1):  $$    D = S  $$ Hill-Shannon Diversity (ℓ ≈ 0):  $$    D = e^{-\sum_{=1}^{S} p_i \ln(p_i)}  $$ Hill-Simpson Diversity (ℓ = -1):  $$    D = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{S} p_i^2}  $$ Richness uses arithmetic scale (arithmetic mean), thus giving rare species lot leverage. contrast, Hill-Shannon diversity uses logarithmic scale (geometric mean), treating common rare species equally, Hill-Simpson diversity uses reciprocal scale (harmonic mean), giving common species higher leverage. Hill diversity values can estimated different standardisation procedures way mitigate effects sample size sampling biases. One way equalising sample size calculating species accumulation curve (plot cumulative species richness function sample size) year grid cell. smallest sample size among grid cells years dataset used reference select richness values curve. called rarefaction. also possible use larger sample size reference, requires extrapolation smaller samples, prone error rarefaction. However, results sample-size based estimation can problematic depend richness evenness. sample community even distribution individuals across species likely show higher richness sample size community many species rare, rare species less likely appear sample. Similarly, community containing lot species appear less rich actually sample size used comparison small. Detectability also plays important part; hard detect species less likely appear sample, communities rare species easily detectable likely yield richer samples. Another way estimate species richness standardise coverage. iNEXT package (Chao et al., 2014; Hsieh et al., 2016) R used estimate species richness equal level coverage (e.g. 0.95) cell year biodiversity data cube. Coverage proportion individuals community belonging species sample. , coverage 0.95, 95% individuals community belong species detected sample 5% belong species detected sample. Coverage estimated based frequencies species already sample. can illustrated using species accumulation curve, slope represents probability detecting new species next individual sample community. sample size zero, slope one, meaning next individual sampled 100% probability species already sample. Therefore, coverage value one corresponds asymptote species accumulation curve (slope zero), meaning new species uncovered sampling.

K., & Ellison, . M. (2014). Rarefaction extrapolation Hill numbers: framework sampling estimation species diversity studies. Ecological monographs, 84(1), 45-67. Hsieh, T. C., Ma, K. H., & Chao, . (2016). iNEXT: R package rarefaction extrapolation species diversity (Hill numbers). Methods Ecology Evolution, 7(12), 1451-1456.

text: S3 object classes 'indicator_ts' 'occ_turnover' containing calculated indicator values metadata.

title: Calculate Occupancy Turnover — occ_turnover_ts
text: Occupancy turnover measures change species composition time, reflecting rate species appear disappear given area. provides insights dynamic nature ecological communities, highlighting shifts species distributions potential environmental changes. High turnover rates may indicate rapid community restructuring, potentially driven factors habitat alteration, climate change, invasive species. Analyzing occupancy turnover can crucial understanding ecosystem stability, identifying areas conservation concern, assessing effectiveness management strategies. Occupancy turnover can calculated different ways, use Jaccard dissimilarity index (Jaccard, 1901) measure similarity two sets species occurrences. Jaccard index calculated : $$   J = (b + c) / (+ b + c) $$ number species present time periods, b number species present first time period, c number species present second time period. index ranges 0 (turnover) 1 (complete turnover).

title: Calculate Occupancy Turnover — occ_turnover_ts
text: Jaccard, P. (1901). Étude de la distribution florale dans une portion des Alpes et du Jura. Bulletin de la Société Vaudoise des Science Naturelles, 37(142), 547-579.

title: Calculate Evenness Over Time or Space — pielou_evenness_map
text: Species evenness commonly used indicator measures uniformly individuals distributed across species region time. provides complement richness taking relative abundance account. Although GBIF provides information abundances individual counts, majority entries lack information. Hence, evenness can calculated using proportions observations rather proportions individuals. Strictly speaking, evenness measures therefore indicate uniformly species represented respective data set rather true evenness ecological community.

title: Calculate Evenness Over Time or Space — pielou_evenness_map
text: Pielou's evenness (1966) well-known commonly used evenness measure. calculated : $$  E = \frac{-\sum_{=1}^{S} p_i \ln(p_i)}{\ln(S)} $$ S number species pi proportion occurrences represented species .

title: Calculate Evenness Over Time or Space — pielou_evenness_map
text: analysis evenness properties Kvålseth (2015) showed evenness index introduced Williams 1977 unpublished manuscript two important properties Pielou's . properties question complex mathematical properties known Schur-Concavity value validity, attempt describe simply. measure evenness Schur-concave, means distribution individuals becomes evenly spread across species, measure evenness stay increase, never decrease. Value validity means evenness index provide sensible meaningful values across range given distribution species abundances. Kvålseth referred evenness measure E9 refer Williams' evenness. Williams' evenness calculated : $$   1 - \sqrt{\frac{S\sum_{=1}^{S} p_i^2 - 1}{S - 1}} $$ S number species pi proportion occurrences represented species .

Default lightsteelblue. envelopealpha Transparency smoothed trendline envelope. Default 0.2. smooth_cialpha Transparency smoothed lines forming edges trendline envelope. Default 1. point_line Whether plot indicator line series points. Options "line" "point". Default "point". pointsize Size points point_line = "point". Default 2. linewidth Width line point_line = "line". Default 1. ci_type Whether plot bootstrapped confidence intervals "ribbon" "error_bars". Default "error_bars". error_width Width error bars ci_type = "error_bars". Default 1. Note unlike default 'width' parameter geom_errorbar, 'error_width' dependent number data points plot. automatically scaled account . Therefore width select consistent relative plot width even change 'min_year' 'max_year'. error_thickness Thickness error bars ci_type = "error_bars". Default 1. smooth_linetype Type line plot smoothed trendline. Default "solid". smooth_linewidth Line width smoothed trendline. Default 1. smooth_cilinewidth Line width smoothed trendline confidence intervals. Default 1. gridoff TRUE, hides gridlines. x_label Label x-axis. y_label Label y-axis. x_expand (Optional)  Expansion factor expand x-axis beyond data. Left right values required form c(0.1, 0.2). Default c(0,0). y_expand (Optional)  Expansion factor expand y-axis beyond data. Lower upper values required form c(0.1, 0.2). Default c(0,0). x_breaks Integer giving desired number breaks x axis. (May return exactly number requested.) y_breaks Integer giving desired number breaks y axis. (May return exactly number requested.) wrap_length Maximum title length wrapping new line.

code: process_cube(   cube_name,   grid_type = c("automatic", "eea", "mgrs", "eqdgc", "custom", "none"),   first_year = NULL,   last_year = NULL,   force_gridcode = FALSE,   cols_year = NULL,   cols_yearMonth = NULL,   cols_cellCode = NULL,   cols_occurrences = NULL,   cols_scientificName = NULL,   cols_minCoordinateUncertaintyInMeters = NULL,   cols_minTemporalUncertainty = NULL,   cols_kingdom = NULL,   cols_family = NULL,   cols_species = NULL,   cols_kingdomKey = NULL,   cols_familyKey = NULL,   cols_speciesKey = NULL,   cols_familyCount = NULL,   cols_sex = NULL,   cols_lifeStage = NULL )

title: Process GBIF Data Cubes — process_cube
text: cube_name location name data cube file (e.g., 'inst/extdata/europe_species_cube.csv'). grid_type Specify grid reference system cube uses. default function attempt determine automatically return error fails. want perform analysis cube custom grid codes (e.g. output gcube package) cube without grid codes, select 'custom' 'none', respectively. first_year (Optional) first year occurrences include. specified, uses default 1600 prevent false records (e.g. year = 0). last_year (Optional) final year occurrences include. specified, uses latest year present cube. force_gridcode Force function assume specific grid reference system. may cause unexpected downstream issues, recommended. getting errors related grid cell codes, check make sure valid. cols_year name column containing year occurrence (something 'year'). column required unless yearMonth column. cols_yearMonth name column containing year month occurrence (present 'yearMonth'). Use year column. b3gbi package use month data, function convert yearMonth column year column. cols_cellCode name column containing grid reference codes ('cellCode'). column required. cols_occurrences name column containing number occurrence ('occurrences'). column required. cols_scientificName name column containing scientific name species ('scientificName'). Note necessary species column scientificName column. One sufficient. cols_minCoordinateUncertaintyInMeters name column containing minimum coordinate uncertainty occurrences ('minCoordinateUncertaintyinMeters'). cols_minTemporalUncertainty name column containing minimum temporal uncertainty occurrences ('minTemporalUncertainty'). cols_kingdom name column containing kingdom occurring species belongs ('kingdom'). column optional. cols_family name column containing family occurring species belongs ('family'). column optional. cols_species name column containing name occurring species ('species'). Note necessary species column scientificName column. One sufficient. cols_kingdomKey name column containing kingdom key occurring species ('kingdomKey'). column optional. cols_familyKey name column containing family key occurring species ('familykey'). column optional. cols_speciesKey name column containing species key occurring species ('speciesKey'). column required, note 'taxonKey' column can provide speciesKey. cols_familyCount name column containing occurrence count family. column optional. cols_sex name column containing sex observed individuals. column optional. cols_lifeStage name column containing life stage observed individuals. column optional.

title: Calculate Taxonomic Distinctness Over Space or Time — tax_distinct_map
text: S3 object classes 'indicator_map' 'indicator_ts' 'tax_distinct' containing calculated indicator values metadata.

title: Calculate Taxonomic Distinctness Over Space or Time — tax_distinct_map
text: Taxonomic distinctness essential biodiversity variable (EBV) measures taxonomic relatedness species, providing measure biodiversity accounts evolutionary relationships. distance matrix based pairwise taxonomic relationships calculated cell using taxize package (Chamberlain & Szöcs, 2013; Chamberlain et al., 2020), taxonomic distinctness calculated Taxonomic Distinctness Index (TDI; Clarke & Warwick, 1999): $$  \frac{\sum\sum_{<j} \frac{|R_i - R_j|}{L}}{\frac{S(S-1)}{2}} $$ S number species, Ri Rj taxonomic ranks species j (GBIF Taxonomic Backbone), L maximum number taxonomic ranks. TDI ranges 0 1, higher values indicating greater taxonomic distinctness.

title: Calculate Taxonomic Distinctness Over Space or Time — tax_distinct_map
text: tax_distinct_map(): tax_distinct_ts():

title: Calculate Taxonomic Distinctness Over Space or Time — tax_distinct_map
text: Chamberlain, S. ., & Szöcs, E. (2013). taxize: taxonomic search retrieval R. F1000Research, 2. Chamberlain, S., Szoecs, E., Foster, Z., Boettiger, C., Ram, K., Bartomeus, ., Baumgartner, J., O'Donnell, J., Oksanen, J., Tzovaras, B. G., Marchand, P., Tran, V., Salmon, M., Li, G., & Grenié, M. (2020). taxize: Taxonomic Information Around Web. R package version 0.9.98. https://github.com/ropensci/taxize. Clarke, K. R., & Warwick, R. M. (1999). taxonomic distinctness measure biodiversity: weighting step lengths hierarchical levels. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 184, 21-29.

title: b3gbi 0.5.2 - Minor update:
text: Fixed species occurrence species range plots selecting one species (previously possible add additional ggplot code one species plotted due bug plotting code).

title: b3gbi 0.5.1 - Minor update:
text: Equations pkgdown help website now display correctly. Fixed bad example spec_occ_ts() documentation.

title: b3gbi 0.5.0 - Major update:
text: Conversion input output coordinate reference systems now handled correctly even different units (e.g. degrees vs km). Conversion CRSs different units (e.g. degrees vs km) must now forced user, warning given. extensive documentation now provided indicator functions, including formulas background information. Users can now provide external shapefiles limit indicator calculations feature boundaries. Removed compatibility previous generation cubes (created using TriAs project code).

title: b3gbi 0.4.4 - Minor update:
text: Area longer calculated projections use degrees. Occurrence density now refuses calculate projections use degrees. Object metadata now displays ‘degrees’ instead ‘degrees^2’.

title: b3gbi 0.4.3
text: 04.03.2025 - Minor update: Add power parameter map legend scale transformations. enables use Box-Cox, modulus, Yeo-Johnson transformations.

title: b3gbi 0.4.2
text: 20.02.2025 - Minor update: Bug fix: Coordinates now display correctly using process_cube() custom grid codes

title: b3gbi 0.4.1
text: 19.02.2025 - Minor update: R CMD checks now passing without errors, warnings notes ‘taxize’ package longer dependency, must installed want calculate taxonomic distinctness

title: b3gbi 0.4
text: 14.02.2025 - Major update: Better integration rnaturalearth Fully supports b3gbi GUI functions Hill diversity functions now exported can used

title: b3gbi 0.3.1
text: 12.02.2025 - Minor update: Get dependencies recognised repositories Join R-universe!

title: b3gbi 0.3
text: 05.12.2024 - Major update: Added bootstrapped confidence intervals indicators. Added many additional customization parameters time series plots. See plot_ts() documentation. Defaults visualization parameters changed. Fixed bug caused errors incorrect cell sizes actually correct.

title: b3gbi 0.2.3.1
text: 20.11.2024 - Minor update: User-supplied resolutions ‘km’-based grid systems now properly handled

title: b3gbi 0.2.3
text: 07.11.2024 - Minor update: Compatible gcube output: added class sim_cube objects without grid codes added ‘none’ grid_type options Bug fixes: longer returns error correctly specify cell size calculating indicators mgrs grid

title: b3gbi 0.2.2
text: 16.07.2024 - Minor update: Cubes processed using process_cube_old() now column called minCoordinateUncertaintyInMeters, containing spatial uncertainty cube. Previously spatial uncertainty column made available using process_cube() ignored process_cube_old().

title: b3gbi 0.2.1
text: 27.06.2024 - Minor update: Added options improve control plot output. argument land_fill_colour allows change colour land area outside grid.argument crop_to_grid snap plot edges gridded area. improve way plot looks e.g. data sparse extend edges country continent. Fixed bug process_cube_old caused fail. Fixed bug caused calculated indicator objects retain many data columns.

title: b3gbi 0.2.0
text: 24.06.2024 - Major update: Added occupancy turnover available indicators. indicators package now working (can get list typing ‘available_indicators’). process_cube function now expects current generation cube (created using GBIF API) default. Previous generation cubes (created using TriAS project code) can still used must now processed using separate function, process_cube_old. Added support non-standard column names (can manually input column names processing cube, process_cube function rename Darwin Core standard expected rest package). Added support Quarter Degree Military grids (note Military grids translated external package CRAN. hoped replace native code later update). Process_cube function can now automatically find column containing grid cell codes detect type grid (options manually input column name grid cell type cases better leave automatic avoid potential downstream problems). can now select output CRS want use calculated indicator.
